Species Codes

2019-04-25

Source: vignettes/species-codes.Rmd
species-codes.Rmd
library(naturecounts)

In order to download data pertaining to specific species, you’ll have to get the species id codes. These are numeric codes that reflect species identity, and in complex cases, take account of subspecies or changes to species identity.

For all species, you can search by scientific, English or French name with the species_search() function.

For birds, you can also search by alphanumeric species codes with the species_code_search() function. Note: These alphanumeric codes are not the ones used by naturecounts, but are ones used by various taxonomic authorities. This function also gives you the option of returning all species codes (including subspecies, etc.) related to a single species, and is considered a more robust method for ensuring that you do not miss observations.

Searching by name

The simplest way to determine a species id (and the only way, for non-avian taxa) is to use the species_search() function which searches for a species id according to scientific, English or French name and returns a data frame of taxonomic information for all related hits:

species_search("moose")
#>   species_id scientific_name english_name french_name taxon_group
#> 1     133990     Alces alces        Moose        <NA>     MAMMALS
species_search("swallowtail")
#>   species_id     scientific_name               english_name
#> 1     252492     Battus philenor       Pipevine Swallowtail
#> 2     252493 Eurytides marcellus          Zebra Swallowtail
#> 3     252494   Papilio polyxenes          Black Swallowtail
#> 4     252495     Papilio machaon      Old World Swallowtail
#> 5     252496 Papilio cresphontes          Giant Swallowtail
#> 6     252497     Papilio glaucus  Eastern Tiger Swallowtail
#> 7     252498  Papilio canadensis Canadian Tiger Swallowtail
#> 8     252499     Papilio troilus      Spicebush Swallowtail
#>                 french_name taxon_group
#> 1 Papillon de l'aristoloche    BUTTERFL
#> 2            Papillon zébré    BUTTERFL
#> 3        Papillon du céleri    BUTTERFL
#> 4                   Machaon    BUTTERFL
#> 5         Grand porte-queue    BUTTERFL
#> 6   Papillon tigré de l'Est    BUTTERFL
#> 7  Papillon tigré du Canada    BUTTERFL
#> 8       Papillon carolinien    BUTTERFL
species_search("mesange a tete noire")
#>   species_id                           scientific_name
#> 1      14280                      Poecile atricapillus
#> 2      40932            Poecile atricapillus x gambeli
#> 3      44462         Poecile atricapillus x hudsonicus
#> 4      44466 Poecile atricapillus x Baeolophus bicolor
#> 5      45746              Poecile atricapillus/gambeli
#>                                        english_name
#> 1                            Black-capped Chickadee
#> 2        Black-capped x Mountain Chickadee (hybrid)
#> 3          Black-capped x Boreal Chickadee (hybrid)
#> 4 Black-capped Chickadee x Tufted Titmouse (hybrid)
#> 5                   Black-capped/Mountain Chickadee
#>                                      french_name taxon_group
#> 1                           Mésange à tête noire       BIRDS
#> 2    Hybride Mésange à tête noire x M. de Gambel       BIRDS
#> 3 Hybride Mésange à tête noire x M. à tête brune       BIRDS
#> 4     Hybride Mésange à tête noire x M. bicolore       BIRDS
#> 5           Mésange à tête noire ou M. de Gambel       BIRDS

These species ids can then be used to download data either directly:

moose <- nc_data_dl(species = 133990, verbose = FALSE, username = "sample")

Or by saving and referencing the data frame:

moose_id <- species_search("moose")$species_id
moose <- nc_data_dl(species = moose_id, verbose = FALSE, username = "sample")

This might be considered overkill for a single species, but is useful when you want to download data for multiple species:

chickadee_ids <- species_search("chickadee")$species_id
chickadees <- nc_data_dl(species = chickadee_ids, 
                         verbose = FALSE, username = "sample")

Searching by alphanumeric code

Taxonomy for bird species has long included various alphanumeric codes from different taxonomic authorities. The codes often include separate codes for recognized subdivisions of the species (subspecies, subpopulations, hybrids, etc.). The species_code_search() allows you to search for avian species ids according to these authorities.

Authorities

The default taxonomic authority used is BSCDATA, which uses 4-letter alpha codes:

species_code_search("BCCH")
#>   species_id BSCDATA      scientific_name           english_name
#> 1      14280    BCCH Poecile atricapillus Black-capped Chickadee
#>            french_name
#> 1 Mésange à tête noire

The search function is case insensitive:

species_code_search("bcch")
#>   species_id BSCDATA      scientific_name           english_name
#> 1      14280    BCCH Poecile atricapillus Black-capped Chickadee
#>            french_name
#> 1 Mésange à tête noire

However, you can search by codes for different authorities, by specifying the appropriate authority argument:

species_code_search(8868, authority = "CBC")
#>   species_id  CBC      scientific_name           english_name
#> 1      14280 8868 Poecile atricapillus Black-capped Chickadee
#>            french_name
#> 1 Mésange à tête noire

All related subspecies

By default, the search_species_codes() returns all species ids related to the search term.

For example, searching for myrtle warblers (MYWA), one of two subspecies of the yellow-rumped warbler (YRWA) returns both subspecies and the parent species.

species_code_search("MYWA")
#>   species_id BSCDATA             scientific_name
#> 1      16610    YRWA          Setophaga coronata
#> 2      16620    MYWA Setophaga coronata coronata
#> 3      16630    AUWA Setophaga coronata auduboni
#>                        english_name                          french_name
#> 1             Yellow-rumped Warbler            Paruline à croupion jaune
#> 2    Yellow-rumped Warbler (Myrtle) Paruline à croupion jaune (coronata)
#> 3 Yellow-rumped Warbler (Audubon's) Paruline à croupion jaune (auduboni)

Note: Different taxonomic authorities recognize different subgroups.

For example, BSCDATA recognizes 4 groups for dark-eyed juncos:

species_code_search("DEJU")
#>   species_id BSCDATA                                  scientific_name
#> 1      42218    DEJU                                   Junco hyemalis
#> 2      19090    SCJU Junco hyemalis hyemalis/carolinensis/cismontanus
#> 3      19100    ORJU                  Junco hyemalis [oreganus Group]
#> 4      19110    PSJU                           Junco hyemalis mearnsi
#>                                  english_name
#> 1                             Dark-eyed Junco
#> 2 Dark-eyed Junco (Slate-colored/cismontanus)
#> 3                    Dark-eyed Junco (Oregon)
#> 4                Dark-eyed Junco (Pink-sided)
#>                                             french_name
#> 1                                         Junco ardoisé
#> 2 Junco ardoisé [hyemalis, carolinensis ou cismontanus]
#> 3                              Junco ardoisé [oreganus]
#> 4                               Junco ardoisé (mearnsi)

Whereas CBC also recognizes sub group hybrids (and the Guadalupe junco):

species_code_search("12385", authority = "CBC")
#>    species_id   CBC                                  scientific_name
#> 1       42218 12385                                   Junco hyemalis
#> 2       19090 12386 Junco hyemalis hyemalis/carolinensis/cismontanus
#> 3       41434 12388                       Junco hyemalis cismontanus
#> 4       19100 12389                  Junco hyemalis [oreganus Group]
#> 5       19110 12390                           Junco hyemalis mearnsi
#> 6       42219 12391                Junco hyemalis oreganus x mearnsi
#> 7       19112 12392                            Junco hyemalis aikeni
#> 8       19111 12394                          Junco hyemalis caniceps
#> 9       42220 12395                Junco hyemalis mearnsi x caniceps
#> 10      40859 12396                          Junco hyemalis dorsalis
#> 11      39768 12398                                  Junco insularis
#>                                   english_name
#> 1                              Dark-eyed Junco
#> 2  Dark-eyed Junco (Slate-colored/cismontanus)
#> 3                Dark-eyed Junco (cismontanus)
#> 4                     Dark-eyed Junco (Oregon)
#> 5                 Dark-eyed Junco (Pink-sided)
#> 6        Dark-eyed Junco (Oregon x Pink-sided)
#> 7               Dark-eyed Junco (White-winged)
#> 8                Dark-eyed Junco (Gray-headed)
#> 9   Dark-eyed Junco (Pink-sided x Gray-headed)
#> 10                Dark-eyed Junco (Red-backed)
#> 11                             Guadalupe Junco
#>                                              french_name
#> 1                                          Junco ardoisé
#> 2  Junco ardoisé [hyemalis, carolinensis ou cismontanus]
#> 3                            Junco ardoisé (cismontanus)
#> 4                               Junco ardoisé [oreganus]
#> 5                                Junco ardoisé (mearnsi)
#> 6                     Junco ardoisé (oreganus x mearnsi)
#> 7                 Junco ardoisé (forme à ailes blanches)
#> 8                               Junco ardoisé (caniceps)
#> 9                     Junco ardoisé (mearnsi x caniceps)
#> 10                              Junco ardoisé (dorsalis)
#> 11                                    Junco de Guadalupe

You can search by more than one authority at the same time. Note that your search term only needs to match one authority (not both), and that the information returned reflects both authorities combined.

species_code_search("DEJU", authority = c("BSCDATA", "CBC"))
#>    species_id BSCDATA   CBC
#> 1       42218    DEJU 12385
#> 2       19100    ORJU 12389
#> 3       19110    PSJU 12390
#> 4       19090    SCJU 12386
#> 5       41434    <NA> 12388
#> 6       42219    <NA> 12391
#> 7       19112    <NA> 12392
#> 8       19111    <NA> 12394
#> 9       42220    <NA> 12395
#> 10      40859    <NA> 12396
#> 11      39768    <NA> 12398
#>                                     scientific_name
#> 1                                    Junco hyemalis
#> 2                   Junco hyemalis [oreganus Group]
#> 3                            Junco hyemalis mearnsi
#> 4  Junco hyemalis hyemalis/carolinensis/cismontanus
#> 5                        Junco hyemalis cismontanus
#> 6                 Junco hyemalis oreganus x mearnsi
#> 7                             Junco hyemalis aikeni
#> 8                           Junco hyemalis caniceps
#> 9                 Junco hyemalis mearnsi x caniceps
#> 10                          Junco hyemalis dorsalis
#> 11                                  Junco insularis
#>                                   english_name
#> 1                              Dark-eyed Junco
#> 2                     Dark-eyed Junco (Oregon)
#> 3                 Dark-eyed Junco (Pink-sided)
#> 4  Dark-eyed Junco (Slate-colored/cismontanus)
#> 5                Dark-eyed Junco (cismontanus)
#> 6        Dark-eyed Junco (Oregon x Pink-sided)
#> 7               Dark-eyed Junco (White-winged)
#> 8                Dark-eyed Junco (Gray-headed)
#> 9   Dark-eyed Junco (Pink-sided x Gray-headed)
#> 10                Dark-eyed Junco (Red-backed)
#> 11                             Guadalupe Junco
#>                                              french_name
#> 1                                          Junco ardoisé
#> 2                               Junco ardoisé [oreganus]
#> 3                                Junco ardoisé (mearnsi)
#> 4  Junco ardoisé [hyemalis, carolinensis ou cismontanus]
#> 5                            Junco ardoisé (cismontanus)
#> 6                     Junco ardoisé (oreganus x mearnsi)
#> 7                 Junco ardoisé (forme à ailes blanches)
#> 8                               Junco ardoisé (caniceps)
#> 9                     Junco ardoisé (mearnsi x caniceps)
#> 10                              Junco ardoisé (dorsalis)
#> 11                                    Junco de Guadalupe

Exact species

If you do not want all subgroups, you can use the results = "exact" argument to return only an exact match.

species_code_search("DEJU", results = "exact")
#>   species_id BSCDATA scientific_name    english_name   french_name
#> 1      42218    DEJU  Junco hyemalis Dark-eyed Junco Junco ardoisé
species_code_search("ORJU", results = "exact")
#>   species_id BSCDATA                 scientific_name
#> 1      19100    ORJU Junco hyemalis [oreganus Group]
#>               english_name              french_name
#> 1 Dark-eyed Junco (Oregon) Junco ardoisé [oreganus]

Advanced searches

If you have a very specific type of search you’d like to do, you may be better off using the filter() function from the dplyr package.

library(dplyr)

For example, let’s assume you’re interested in collecting species codes for in the Muridae family.

We can get the entire species list by omitting a search term, and also return all taxonomic information available with the show = "all" argument.

all <- species_search(show = "all")
head(all)
#>   species_id       concept_id          scientific_name species_status
#> 1          0 74B5AA0128689718                      N/A             NA
#> 2         10 42D72AE118D2DE82            Tinamus major              1
#> 3         20 66C31E09F8C285D6   Nothocercus bonapartei              1
#> 4         30 39DD9DD76680A7F0        Crypturellus soui              1
#> 5         40 AAB5CEED3FC9EDE1 Crypturellus cinnamomeus              1
#> 6         50 5183B60E14DE99FD    Crypturellus boucardi              1
#>   added_dt           english_name          french_name   phylum
#> 1     <NA>        No observations   Aucune observation     <NA>
#> 2     <NA>          Great Tinamou        Grand Tinamou Chordata
#> 3     <NA>       Highland Tinamou Tinamou de Bonaparte Chordata
#> 4     <NA>         Little Tinamou         Tinamou soui Chordata
#> 5     <NA>        Thicket Tinamou     Tinamou cannelle Chordata
#> 6     <NA> Slaty-breasted Tinamou   Tinamou de Boucard Chordata
#>   family_french_name group_id  order_taxon taxon_group sort_order class
#> 1 Aucune observation    99999         <NA>       BIRDS     999999  <NA>
#> 2               <NA>        3 Tinamiformes       BIRDS         17  Aves
#> 3               <NA>        3 Tinamiformes       BIRDS         10  Aves
#> 4               <NA>        3 Tinamiformes       BIRDS         22  Aves
#> 5               <NA>        3 Tinamiformes       BIRDS         39  Aves
#> 6               <NA>        3 Tinamiformes       BIRDS         36  Aves
#>   family_name concept_source family_english_name
#> 1        <NA>        avibase     No observations
#> 2   Tinamidae        avibase            Tinamous
#> 3   Tinamidae        avibase            Tinamous
#> 4   Tinamidae        avibase            Tinamous
#> 5   Tinamidae        avibase            Tinamous
#> 6   Tinamidae        avibase            Tinamous

Now we can search for the family

mice_ids <- filter(all, family_name == "Muridae")
head(mice_ids)
#>   species_id       concept_id     scientific_name species_status added_dt
#> 1     139860 CA7511C47A77B567  Alticola albicauda              1     <NA>
#> 2     139870 20968C4C26EBF16E Alticola argentatus              1     <NA>
#> 3     139880 45B93B3397553E4A  Alticola barakshin              1     <NA>
#> 4     139890 85588495C41CCF64   Alticola lemminus              1     <NA>
#> 5     139900 4BEBDB13A8E2F028   Alticola macrotis              1     <NA>
#> 6     139910 FBE48923651EFBA5    Alticola montosa              1     <NA>
#>   english_name french_name   phylum family_french_name group_id
#> 1         <NA>        <NA> Chordata            Muridae     2111
#> 2         <NA>        <NA> Chordata            Muridae     2111
#> 3         <NA>        <NA> Chordata            Muridae     2111
#> 4         <NA>        <NA> Chordata            Muridae     2111
#> 5         <NA>        <NA> Chordata            Muridae     2111
#> 6         <NA>        <NA> Chordata            Muridae     2111
#>   order_taxon taxon_group sort_order    class family_name concept_source
#> 1    Rodentia     MAMMALS     139860 Mammalia     Muridae        avibase
#> 2    Rodentia     MAMMALS     139870 Mammalia     Muridae        avibase
#> 3    Rodentia     MAMMALS     139880 Mammalia     Muridae        avibase
#> 4    Rodentia     MAMMALS     139890 Mammalia     Muridae        avibase
#> 5    Rodentia     MAMMALS     139900 Mammalia     Muridae        avibase
#> 6    Rodentia     MAMMALS     139910 Mammalia     Muridae        avibase
#>   family_english_name
#> 1             Muridae
#> 2             Muridae
#> 3             Muridae
#> 4             Muridae
#> 5             Muridae
#> 6             Muridae
length(mice_ids$species_id)
#> [1] 1331

So there are a lot of muridae species! But probably not that many in the actual database. We can download all available observations of these species, by passing the species_ids to the nc_data_dl() function.

mice <- nc_data_dl(species = mice_ids$species_id, 
                   verbose = FALSE, username = "sample")
mice
#>                                 GlobalUniqueIdentifier FieldNumber
#> 1   URN:catalog:PEMBROKEFN:RCBIOTABASE:7908-1-151590-5          NA
#> 2 URN:catalog:PEMBROKEFN:RCBIOTABASE:11527-1-141160-16          NA
#>   DurationInHours ObservationDescriptor5 Remarks ObservationDescriptor6
#> 1               1                     NA      NA                     NA
#> 2               5                     NA      NA                     NA
#>   project_id ObservationDescriptor3 ObservationDescriptor4
#> 1       1030                     NA                     NA
#> 2       1030                     NA                     NA
#>   ObservationDescriptor ProtocolCode ObservationCount
#> 1                    NA    CHECKLIST                1
#> 2                    NA    CHECKLIST                3
#>   ObservationDescriptor2 TimeIntervalEnded longitude   Locality
#> 1                     NA                NA -77.35851 Black Bay*
#> 2                     NA                NA -77.02515   Mud Lake
#>   SamplingEventIdentifier  collection protocol_id SurveyAreaIdentifier
#> 1      RCBIOTABASE-7908-1 RCBIOTABASE          50                   NA
#> 2     RCBIOTABASE-11527-1 RCBIOTABASE          50                   NA
#>   SamplingEventStructure protocol_type country_code TimeCollected
#> 1                     NA            10           CA         21.25
#> 2                     NA            10           CA            10
#>   statprov_code TimeObservationsEnded species_id utm_square
#> 1            ON                 22.25     151590    18TUR18
#> 2            ON                  <NA>     141160    18TUR46
#>   TimeObservationsStarted latitude iba_site CollectorNumber bcr
#> 1                   21.25 45.87065      N/A         1031370  12
#> 2                      10 45.72979      N/A         1031229  13

#> 1            6   7908-1-151590-5                Yes        2012
#> 2            6 11527-1-141160-16                Yes        2013
#>   ProjectCode RouteIdentifier AllIndividualsReported TimeIntervalsAdditive

#> 2 RCBIOTABASE              NA                    Yes                    NA
#>                               ProtocolURL NumberOfObservers SiteCode
#> 1 http://www.birdscanada.org/birdmon/rcb/                NA       NA
#> 2 http://www.birdscanada.org/birdmon/rcb/                NA       NA
#>   ObservationCount2 subnational2_code survey_week survey_day record_id
#> 1                NA          CA.ON.RE           2          9 968040828

#> 2            NA                NA                NA    Checklist

Only 2 observations!
